articles.headline: Obama Endorses Hillary Clinton, and Urges Democrats to Unite
articles.snippet: With Senator Bernie Sanders still in the race, the president said the stakes were too high to let divisions stand in the way of defeating Donald J. Trump.
articles.abstract: With Senator Bernie Sanders still in the race, the president said the stakes were too high to let divisions stand in the way of defeating Donald J. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama told Senator Bernie Sanders in an Oval Office meeting on Thursday to channel the energy of his presidential campaign’s millions of supporters behind Hillary Clinton, and said that Mr. Sanders would play a central role in shaping the Democratic agenda if he did.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: How Keeping Up Appearances Ruined a Former Dallas Banker
articles.snippet: S.E.C. and criminal complaints paint Thomas C. Davis, considered a pillar of the business community, as a man in “desperate” financial straits.
articles.abstract: S.E.C. and criminal complaints paint Thomas C. Davis, considered a pillar of the business community, as a man in “desperate” financial straits.
articles.lead_paragraph: At age 67, Thomas C. Davis should be enjoying all the perks of a long and distinguished career at the pinnacle of Wall Street and the Texas business elite. These include golfing at the prestigious Dallas Country Club and Preston Trail Golf Club, where he was a member; trips to Las Vegas and golf tournaments on the private jet he co-owned; and fractional ownership of two professional sports teams, the Texas Rangers and the Dallas Stars.

articles.headline: Viacom Rumblings: Stacking the Board and Maybe Remerging With CBS
articles.snippet: An effort to replace some directors is said to be underway, and there may be a possibility of recombining Viacom and CBS, which split in 2006.
articles.abstract: An effort to replace some directors is said to be underway, and there may be a possibility of recombining Viacom and CBS, which split in 2006.
articles.lead_paragraph: National Amusements, the theater chain through which Sumner M. Redstone controls his $40 billion empire, is preparing to replace a handful of directors on the Viacom board, a move that is expected to serve as a prelude to the ouster of the company’s embattled chief executive.

articles.headline: Tighter Rules on Money Transfers Put Squeeze on Businesses
articles.snippet: Banks are refusing to do business with money transmitters, closing or freezing accounts over concerns about money laundering and regulatory scrutiny.
articles.abstract: Banks are refusing to do business with money transmitters, closing or freezing accounts over concerns about money laundering and regulatory scrutiny.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Fernando Lopez’s storefront money-transfer business in Atlantic City was a place where local residents could wire money to family and friends abroad. But that business, Interamericana Express, which handled a lot of transmittals to Mexico, is dwindling as banks and regulators take a stricter view of cross-border money transfers.

articles.headline: Volkswagen Not Alone in Flouting Pollution Limits
articles.snippet: Other carmakers in Europe have taken advantage of a loophole that allows them to reduce emissions controls whenever there is risk of engine damage.
articles.abstract: Other carmakers in Europe have taken advantage of a loophole that allows them to reduce emissions controls whenever there is risk of engine damage.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — One diesel car tested by the German government emitted more than 12 times as much poisonous nitrogen oxide as allowed. Another was five times over the limit, and yet another six times over.

articles.headline: Tesla Model S Suspension Failures Under Scrutiny by Safety Agency
articles.snippet: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration also warned Tesla Motors to refrain from encouraging Model S drivers not to report safety concerns.
articles.abstract: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration also warned Tesla Motors to refrain from encouraging Model S drivers not to report safety concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tesla Motors, the maverick electric-car maker, is under scrutiny from federal regulators over suspension failures attributed to its biggest-selling model — along with reports that it had asked owners not to disclose the problem.

articles.headline: A Steel Mill Lives Again, in a Setback for China
articles.snippet: Local officials and businesses buck Beijing’s efforts to close the inefficient industries that are hobbling the country’s economic growth.
articles.abstract: Local officials and businesses buck Beijing’s efforts to close the inefficient industries that are hobbling the country’s economic growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: TANGSHAN, China — The hulking, white-and-brown buildings of the Songting Iron & Steel Company stood silent one chilly February afternoon. The only signs of life came from the handful of guards at the compound’s gate, and from the disheveled middle-aged man who emerged to shout to the plant’s visitors, “Get lost!”

articles.headline: Period. Full Stop. Point. Whatever It’s Called, It’s Going Out of Style
articles.snippet: Language experts say one of the oldest forms of punctuation is going out of fashion, felled by the staccato sentences favored in instant messaging
articles.abstract: Language experts say one of the oldest forms of punctuation is going out of fashion, felled by the staccato sentences favored in instant messaging
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — One of the oldest forms of punctuation may be dying

articles.headline: Where to, Hillary? How Clinton Is Relying on President Obama’s Help
articles.snippet: Clinton strategists see a one-of-a-kind resource: a popular, sitting president who can be deployed to battleground states to drum up support.
articles.abstract: Clinton strategists see a one-of-a-kind resource: a popular, sitting president who can be deployed to battleground states to drum up support.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After George W. Bush twice carried the New Hampshire county that includes vote-rich Manchester and Nashua, President Obama turned the tables and won it in both his elections by similar margins.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Patrick Healy

articles.headline: Greed, Passion, Lust, Betrayal, and the Olympics in Between
articles.snippet: In Brazil, the popular TV serials called telenovelas have so tight a grip on viewers that even the Olympics on home turf take a back seat in prime time.
articles.abstract: In Brazil, the popular TV serials called telenovelas have so tight a grip on viewers that even the Olympics on home turf take a back seat in prime time.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Olympics begin in Rio during the first week of August, the eyes of the world will be watching Brazil. The eyes of Brazil, meanwhile, will be watching Camila Pitanga.

articles.headline: Getting a Reverse Mortgage, but Not From a Celebrity
articles.snippet: Some community bankers are lending respectability to the often-maligned reverse mortgage.
articles.abstract: Some community bankers are lending respectability to the often-maligned reverse mortgage.
articles.lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — If you don’t have a reverse mortgage and don’t know anyone who does, your familiarity with the product probably comes from television commercials. There, often late at night, Pat Boone and Henry Winkler have peddled them with great sincerity.

articles.headline: For Tesla Owner, Losing a Wheel Was Just the First Surprise
articles.snippet: As the automaker defended the safety of its Model S, its request for confidentiality in exchange for repairs raised questions among legal experts.
articles.abstract: As the automaker defended the safety of its Model S, its request for confidentiality in exchange for repairs raised questions among legal experts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pete Cordaro was creeping down a dirt road in his 2013 Tesla Model S electric car, on a Sunday outing with his wife to hunt mushrooms in the Pennsylvania woods, when he encountered a pothole and then heard a loud crack.
articles.byline: By Neal E. Boudette and Annalyn Kurtz
